Title: Black Country Framework for Minor Works - AWARD
Description:
This Framework Contract is required for the provision of highways and civils minor construction works; typically, minor highway improvements, work on bridges and structures, together with other transport related highway and civils engineering construction.
      
      Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council and regional council partners in the West Midlands will need to carry out improvements across the region.
      
      The works will include but are not limited to:
      
      Excavation of existing carriageway, footways, landscape areas and removal of trees;
      Flexible pavement and footway construction;
      Removal and installation of road markings and signing;
      Installation of new drainage;
      Installation of new traffic signals and pedestrian crossings;
      Installation of lighting columns, bollards and electrical connections;
      Infilling of existing subway and associated demolition works;
      Protection to existing underground services if required;
      Co-ordination of Statutory Undertakers works;
      Associated landscape works; and
      Construction of park and ride facilities.
      
      The works required will be broken down into 3 Lots based on financial thresholds (and the implied increased complexity of works and project management) as follows:
      
      The client reserves the right to group together a number of small packages of work to make one larger package. This may move a work package to a different lot.
      
      Lot 1 - Highway and related Civils works up to a value of £100,000.
      Lot 2 - Highway and related Civils works from £100,001 to £500,000.
      Lot 3 - Highway and related Civils works £500,001+
      
      The total cost of works for the length of the framework is currently estimated at between £10m and £50m.
      
      This figure is intended to be used as a guide only and is not a guarantee of the level of business that will be generated from this Framework Agreement.
      
      The Council is purchasing this framework agreement on behalf of the Black Country Local Authorities and another Partner Organisation which comprise of:
      
      Birmingham City Council
      Dudley MBC
      Sandwell MBC
      Walsall MBC
      Wolverhampton City Council
      Wolverhampton Homes
      West Midlands Combined Authority
      
      The Framework Agreement will be for a 3-year period, commencing 1 November 2021 (indicative date), with the option to extend for 1 additional year subject to satisfactory performance and agreement of prices/rates.
      
      Call Off Contracts will be made either via Direct Award or Mini-Competition and will use the NEC3 terms and conditions.
      
      Pricing and quality submissions at the ITT stage will be treated as submissions for the purposes of any direct awards.
      
      Mini-Competition routes will be conducted using a Mini-Competition Invitation to Tender document containing evaluation criteria for companies to respond to.  This evaluation criteria will be assessed using the methodology detailed in the Mini-Competition Invitation to Tender document.

Description:
The work comprises of building works to maintain and restore council housing properties on a day-to-day basis. The contract period will be for two (2) years between 1 January 2022 to 31 December 2023. 
      
      The project excludes major works of refurbishment, re-roofing, and programmed maintenance, all of which are covered by separate agreements unless instructed or directed otherwise.
      
      Properties covered by this contract are within the Metropolitan Borough of Sandwell and consist of municipal housing. The properties covered by this tender include approximately 29,000 domestic dwellings and the work categories specified in this tender will supplement and support the existing Sandwell MBC directly employed workforce to achieve the target completion dates.

Title: The Provision Of 128 DUNE APA Stainless Steel Frames
Description:
The DUNE Anode Plane Assemblies (APAs) will form the major part of the DUNE far site detector. We are finishing the prototype APAs for installation in a cryostat at CERN and preparing for the full production run of up to 128 APAs. The APAs are composed of large stainless steel metal frames and made of thousands of turns of wire, roughly 24 kilometres for each APA. It's an engineering challenge to wind the wire around the frames and build the wire chambers.
      
      A fully assembled frame is expected 'in spec' with all the associated documents or 'doc pack' including material certificates, ITP (Inspection Test plan), mechanical inspections, NDT (Non-Destructive Testing) etc.
      
      Full qualification (inspection) by ourselves will be needed in the first batch of two frames. This will include visual inspection, an inspection of holes and machined parts and welding quality. The company will allow us access to do these qualification checks.

Notice Identifier: ECCBS010 - Energy Savings Opportunity Scheme (ESOS) Behavioural Research
Title: ECCBS010 - Energy Savings Opportunity Scheme (ESOS) Behavioural Research
Description:
**Please note this is an Award Notice not a call for competition** This contract has been awarded via Energy and Climate Change Behavioural Science Framework Agreement. Reference: CR20116.

Brief description of requirement
A 2020 Post-Implementation Review (PIR) of the scheme2 found that whilst 90% of organisations in the evaluation reported having planned or implemented an energy efficiency measure, participants did not always act upon energy savings opportunities identified through their audits, and many perceived ESOS as purely a compliance activity.

The PIR highlighted several areas where ESOS could be strengthened and improved, which resulted in a consultation (July-September 2021) into strengthening the scheme. The specific aims of improving the scheme are:
1.	To increase the number of ESOS participants that take action to reduce energy use by raising the quality of their ESOS audit;
2.	To increase the carbon and cost savings from ESOS by increasing the number and scope of ESOS recommendations taken up by participants;
3.	To ensure that ESOS recommendations are consistent with the UK's net zero commitments. 

This project is seeking to understand whether behaviourally informed interventions could be used to achieve the desired energy efficiency outcomes, as opposed to regulation to require that participants act on recommendations.

This research will provide timely evidence to inform what action is taken from the consultation. This is a joint project with the Better Regulation Executive (BRE), who work closely with teams across Government to encourage the use of non-regulatory measures to achieve policy outcomes.

This research seeks to address aims 1 and 2: to improve the quality of energy audits and increase the number and scope of ESOS recommendations taken up by participants. Currently the content and the format of the ESOS report is at the discretion of ESOS lead assessors rather than participants.

Despite the importance of audit quality in delivering savings for participating businesses, the ESOS evaluation research and the PIR identified discrepancies in the quality of audits and the presentation of recommendations within ESOS reports.

Title: Provision of Quantity Surveying services for Whitehouse Community Meeting Place. Further competition under Professional Services Framework Lot 2 Band C - AWARD
Description:
Quantity Surveying services are required to assist the Built Assets Team in delivering a new community facility on the Whitehouse development in the Western Expansion area of Milton Keynes.  The community meeting place has been designed to RIBA Stage 4 with planning approval.  The construction contract will be tendered to the open market via MKC's tendering portal with the assistance of the procurement team. All associated external works including parking are included as part of the schemes. 
      The QS role will be expected to join the existing project team and pick up the project at its current stage (end of RIBA 
      Stage 4) and prepare the relevant tender documents, evaluate the returns and undertake QS duties in relation to preparation and administration of the contract and works on site, through to completion at RIBA stage 7. Duties will 
      be as specified in the Scope of Service document published with the Mini Competition. The appointed QS is expected 
      to be able to start work on this straight away in January 2022 with the first key task being to undertake a tender cost estimate on the design. This project will be tendered on the open market via the Council's Intend system for a four
      week period and construction on site is estimated at 16-20 weeks. 
      
      To support the delivery of this scheme, the full suite of QS services is required from RIBA Stage 4 through to completion.
      
      Architectural Services, CDM Client Advisor services and Clerk of Works will also be commissioned separately.

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Somerset CCG - Elective Care Services
Description:
Somerset Clinical Commissioning Group (SCCG) is going to award a contract to Nuffield Hospital Taunton for elective care services.

The currently contracted service expires on 31st March 2022.  In making this further award, the Commissioners are awarding a contract for a period of 12 months until 31st March 2023 with an option to extend for a further 12 months. There are no guaranteed activity volumes, however current service is approximately £2m per annum.  The services commissioned are elective care services, predominantly in the specialty of Trauma and Orthopaedics, with some General Surgery and ENT.  The provision also includes Inter Provider Transfers from local NHS Foundations Trusts to ensure the continued support in elective recovery across the Somerset system within the established infrastructure and geographical footprint of Somerset.

The range of services included in the contract support the principles and regulation of patient choice, particularly as it pertains to the NHS Constitution, the Standing Rules Regulations, and the NHS Choice Framework.

Nuffield Health Taunton continues to provide a good quality service that meets the needs and expectation of the Commissioner and Patients, and the Commissioner has no concerns regarding the proposed provider's ability to deliver the service through to April 2023.  As a result of all the material factors noted above, the Negotiated procedure without prior publication has been followed and justified under regulation 32(2)(b)(ii) 'competition is absent for technical reasons'.
Additional Text: The services are healthcare services falling within Schedule 3 to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations") which are not subject to the full regime of the Regulations, but is instead governed by the "Light Touch Regime" contained within Chapter 3, Section 7 of the Regulations (Regulations 74 to 77).

Title: T0249 Intermediate APTR Solutions
Description:
National Highways (the Client) is seeking the provision of services to progress a project with the core objective of examining alternative intermediate interventions that would consistently work in locations that would benefit from an upgrade, but where there isn't a strong enough economic case to provide a dual carriageway with grade separated junctions. This will contribute to our performance goals outlined in the Strategic Business Plan (2020-2025), specifically for improving safety for all, providing fast and reliable journeys, and delivering better environmental outcomes.
This task (Phase 2) builds on the work done to-date. It will consider, for the three road type options identified as viable in the Research into Network Application stage, do detailed analysis to demonstrate how safety, environmental, operational, maintenance, capital and whole life costs are impacted. It will seek to identify the optimum from these three options. The output of this work will then pass to the SES owner of CD127 Cross-Sections and Headrooms to verify the research, to check and challenge, to then decide if a new road type is feasible and that the benefits would align with our National Highways Business Objectives. If any option is deemed feasible it would be debated via the Road Layout Technical Standards Committed for consideration and inclusion in CD 127 Cross-Sections and Headrooms as a new road type.

Title: CO1489 Wiltshire Design & Neighbourhood Planning
Description:
The Wiltshire Core Strategy (WCS) was adopted in January 2015 and sets the strategic framework for planning development across the County until 2026. The WCS is under review and adoption of the Wiltshire Local Plan Review is anticipated by the end of 2023, which will plan for a longer time period and be updated to ensure it reflects current national policy.
The aim of the Wiltshire Design Guide and Codes is to deliver the requirements as set out in the National Design Guide, National Model Design Code, and the recent changes to the NPPF (2021). Title: Minding the Gap
Description:
Minding the Gap is an innovative approach to mental health services for young people aged 16-24 that has a national profile. It was created by Camden Council in partnership with Camden CCG in 2015 and co-designed with young people. The key aim of MTG is to improve transitions between child and adult mental health services, to improve the reach of mental health services for young people aged 16-24 and to destigmatise health services by offering holistic and integrated support Minding the Gap is being procured in two Lots: Lot 1: The Hive Hub: which is an integrated innovative youth hub  Lot 2: The counselling & psychotherapy service and systemic integrative therapy: 
Please note the Highest value stated above includes the extension periods which are at the sole disecretio of the council. For further information on both lots and their respective values please go to EU Supply and down load the tender documents. 

The service was procured through the light touch regime using a process similar to the competitive procedure with negotiation. The  term for each of the contracts is for an initial period of five years, with two options to extend for an additional two years each (potentially nine years in total). The services were procured in two lots as specified below

The Hive Hub: £550,000 per year; or £4,950,000 for the duration of the contract period (Lot 1).

The counselling & psychotherapy service and systemic integrative therapy: £368,000 per year, or £3,312,000 for the duration of the contract period (Lot 2).

Title: CBC-1279-T-LS COVID-19 Community Engagement - AWARD
Description:
This is a collaborative Tender between Central Bedfordshire Council and Bedford Borough Council.
      
      The aim of this mixed methods research project is to engage in a dialogue and establish community connections with population groups disproportionately affected by COVID-19 in Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire. This will enable a better understanding of the views of people within these communities, the reasons for and impact of this, how to tackle related health inequalities and allow solutions to be co-developed.
      
      The Council will provide as much support and information as it can in order to help guide you through the Tender process.  Questions asked together with the Council's response will be made available to all tenderers to ensure a fair and consistent approach to all.

Title: Newark and Sherwood Evening and Night Time Economy Strategy
Description:
Newark and Sherwood District Council (NSDC) is seeking to procure consultants to provide specialist advice and guidance to develop an Evening and Night Time Economy Strategy for the district. NSDC would seek that the Evening and Night Time Economy Strategy covers the four main urban and economic centres in the district: Newark, Southwell, Edwinstowe and Ollerton. For the purpose of this strategy, Newark and Sherwood District Council are defining the evening and night time economy as taking place between 6pm and 6am. This can be divided into two sections: evening economy, occurring between 6pm and 11pm, and night time economy, occurring from 11pm onwards.

This Project has been funded by the European Regional Development Fund (Welcome Back Fund).

The deadline for completed quote submissions to be received on the eTendering Portal is 12:00 noon on 21st December 2021.

The Contract is due to commence in January 2022. The timeframe for this study will be approximately 8-12 Weeks from start of commission, ending by 31st March 2022.

Title: PS21230 - Prosperous Places scoping work: Mapping local use of data, evidence, and academic expertise across UK
Description:
***** THIS IS AN AWARD NOTICE, NOT A CALL FOR COMPETITION *****

This procurement is being concluded following a competitive quote exercise.

Brief Description of Requirement

The UK and devolved government's policy agendas are placing increasing emphasis on 'levelling up', place-based strategies and innovation as means of achieving growth and addressing inequalities. The purpose of this study is to develop the foundation of an evidence-base which seeks to capture the capability and capacity for the development of, access to and use of data and evidence between the UK research base (e.g. universities, institutes, researchers), business, the third sector and public policy at a local level. This study will inform scoping of ESRC's Prosperous Places approach to investing in the social sciences.

Title: Rutland County Council: Quotation for Sustainability Assessment for the Local Plan
Description:
Rutland County Council is issuing this Request for Quotation in respect of Sustainability Assessment (SA) for the Local Plan. \r
\r
The SA must ensure that relevant requirements of the SEA Directive and accompanying SEA Regulations are addressed whilst effectively informing and influencing the plan development process to maximise its contribution to sustainable development.  The process must be robust and withstand scrutiny at Examination.  It will need to comply with national planning policy and guidance.\r
\r
Work has now commenced on the Local Plan and once an initial draft of the Local Plan Issues and Options has been produced, the Council will provide it.  The Council expects the awarded Consultancy to work with the Council and to influence each stage of Plan production.  \r
\r
The deadline for completed quote submissions to be received on the eTendering Portal is 12:00 noon on 21st December 2021. \r
\r
The Contract is due to commence on 1st February 2022.

Title: M25 DBFO Contract Management Support 2022-2025 (Technical, Contractual and Commercial)
Description:
The South East Operations team of National Highways is responsible for two DBFO contracts. The M25 DBFO Contract the largest road PFI (Private Finance Initiative) in Europe and the A249 DBFO.
National Highways are looking to appoint Consultants to provide services to assist the Department's Nominee [DN] in the execution of its duties in respect of both the M25 and the A249 DBFO (PFI) Contracts. These services will focus primarily on providing contractual compliance checks and contractual advice. Other services may need to be provided on an adhoc basis, as and when instructed by the DN.
The successful Consultant shall:
1. On appointment, already be familiar with current National Highways standards and procedures.
2. On appointment, already be familiar with highway asset management strategy and practice.
3. On award, familiarise itself fully with the DBFO Contract data and DBFO Contract documents produced by National Highways.
4. Within two weeks of award be able to provide National Highways and the DN with advice on and support to the DBFO contract.

Title: South Cambridgeshire District Council- Grass Cutting Works at Closed Churchyards
Description:
The Council are seeking a suitably qualified landscaper to carry out grass cutting works at the following three Closed Churchyards: 
•	All Saints, West Wickham Road, Horseheath, Cambridgeshire, CB21 4Q
•	The Parish Church of St Mary the Virgin, 12 Church St, Great Shelford, Cambridge CB22 5EL
•	St. Mary and All Saints Church, Church St, Willingham, Cambridge CB24 5HS
We are offering a contract to run for a three year period (2022 to 2025 inclusive) and will award payment upon completion of each cut.
The three closed churchyards are the maintenance responsibility of South Cambridgeshire District Council (SCDC) and are required to be cut according to the following terms:
•	That 12 cuts shall be undertaken throughout the year at All Saints, Horseheath. This equates to 3-week intervals for the period 1st March to 31st October in each year.
•	That 12 cuts shall be undertaken throughout the year at St. Mary and All Saints Church, Willingham. This equates to 3-week intervals from 1st March to 31st October in each year.
•	That 12 cuts shall be undertaken throughout the year at The Parish Church of St Mary the Virgin, Great Shelford. This equates to 3-week intervals from 1st March to 31st October in each year.
•	That the price of the cuts shall be fixed until the end of 2025.
•	Grass cuttings can be left on the ground.
•	Strimming works to be undertaken per visit around gravestones and monuments excluding the perimeter of church buildings and boundary walls.

If you wish to apply for this tender please visit our online portal; https://procontract.due-north.com/Advert?advertId=d3276c56-0738-ec11-810e-005056b64545

Title: The Provision of a Specialist Residential Short Breaks Service for Young People aged 11 - 19 with Learning Disabilities, Autism and Complex Behavioural Needs (Referred to as The Vines)
Description:
Buckinghamshire Council (BC) is tendering for the provision of a Specialist Residential Short Breaks Service for Learning Disabled Young People aged 11 - 19 with Complex Behavioural Needs. This will be provided in a specifically designed 6 bed residential unit that will be leased to the provider from the Local Authority. 
The provider will need to demonstrate a high level of skill in delivering a service to young people with high levels of complex needs and a robust knowledge of the principles of Positive Behaviour Support (PBS). 
Whilst maintaining the current service delivery the provider will be required to work with BC to optimise service delivery to ensure cost efficiencies whilst maintaining a high-quality service.
The current specialist residential short breaks provision for complex behaviour needs is contracted to an external provider which is due to expire and therefore TUPE may apply.
The contract start date is 1st April 2022. The contract term is 24 months with the option to extend for up to 12 months.
A budget cap has been set at £1,760,000.00 for the initial contract term (24 months).

Title: Parson's Close Recreation Ground - (Inclusive Adventure Playground)
Description:
It is believed that an inclusive adventure playground for Parson's Close Recreation Ground, will meet the needs of local families and will further enhance Parson's Close as a free to use destination park. 

It is considered by Officers that an inclusive play space will help deliver playful opportunities for all abilities. By giving families a rare occasion in spending quality leisure time together in their own community. It would be Officer's intention to work with local community groups and specialist suppliers to design an inclusive play structure that will allow all children to play together at height!
The key for making this project a fantastic success is engaging and learning about how disabilities with complex additional support needs can still be allowed to appreciate the true value of play, in all children's development.

It is the Town Council's intention that this play space will create something truly special for our local families and will complement the recent additions to Parson's Close.

To ensure that time isn't wasted on engaging with suppliers who haven't the skills or experience in the delivery of a truly inclusive play space, Officers are asking for the tender to be limited to inclusive play companies with the experience of having delivered at least 5 similar styled projects.
Attachments: COLLUSIVE TENDERING CERTIFICATE AND CONTRACT VALUE.docx EXPRESSIONS OF INTEREST.docx Standardised Pre-Qualification Questionnaire.docx
Additional Text: Deadline for receipt of Expressions of Interest and return of design and pricing is 15th January 2021 at noon.

Title: Textiles Bring Bank Collection Service - Multi-Borough Framework
Description:
Lewisham Council invites you to submit a Tender for the provision of a textiles bring bank collection service. It is anticipated that the successful tenderer will provide this service in Lewisham and a number of other London Boroughs, though it should be noted that there is no guarantee that all authorities mentioned in the tender documents will call off from this agreement.

Lewisham Council and other Participating Authorities require a contractor to:

i) Supply new textile banks to locations across the London Borough of Lewisham, including one of at the Reuse and Recycling Centre
ii) Empty the banks as required by the Participating Authorities at frequencies to be agreed. Actual schedules to be agreed between the Participating Authorities and the Contractor
iii) Maintain the banks as required by the Participating Authorities at frequencies as determined by the specification and Contractor Method Statements
iv) Pay directly to the Participating Authorities a monthly sum, for the value of the textiles collected.

The main objectives of Lewisham Council and all the other Participating Authorities for the provision of a textile bring bank service are to:

a) Maximise income for the Council and other Participating Authorities;
b) Expand London's textile bring site provision;
c) Deliver a high-quality service;
d) Realise social benefits
e) Increase the tonnage diversion from disposal (either landfill or other) whilst
maximising reuse.

Title: T5R12 Powered and Non-Powered Wheelchairs, Specialist Seating and Associated Repairs
Description:
On behalf of SCCL, CPP is seeking to establish a multi-supplier framework for the supply of patient specific
powered and non-powered wheelchairs, specialist seating, repair and maintenance arrangements and for a
full managed service.
The framework will offer a comprehensive and wide range of suppliers and different products providing
participating authorities and service users with flexibility and choice in meeting specific needs and
requirements. Participating authorities will have the option to procure products on an ad hoc basis or
through more regular and structured bulk purchase arrangements.
The framework is structured by way of Lots as follows:
Lot 1 - Powered Adult Standard Wheelchair
Lot 2 - Powered Adult Configurable/Tilt in Space Wheelchair
Lot 3 - Powered Adult Heavy Duty Wheelchair
Lot 4 - Powered Adult Bariatric Wheelchair 160kg+
Lot 5 - Powered Paediatric Standard Wheelchair
Lot 6 - Powered Paediatric Tilt in Space/Postural Wheelchair
Lot 7 - Non-Powered Adult Standard Lightweight Wheelchair
Lot 8 - Non-Powered Adult Standard Wheelchair
Lot 9 - Non-Powered Adult Configurable/Tilt in Space Wheelchair
Lot 10 - Non-Powered Adult Heavy Duty Wheelchair
Lot 11 - Non-Powered Adult Bariatric Wheelchair 160kg+
Lot 12 - Non-Powered Adult Active Wheelchair
Lot 13 - Non-Powered Paediatric Standard Wheelchair
Lot 14 - Non-Powered Paediatric Tilt in Space/Postural Wheelchair
Lot 15 - Non-Powered Paediatric Active Wheelchair
Lot 16 - Non-Powered Paediatric Tilt in Space/Postural Buggy
Lot 17 - Non-Powered Paediatric Buggy - Intermediate
Lot 18 - Wheel Base - Adult
Lot 19 - Wheel Base - Paediatric
Lot 20 - Adaptive/Modular Seating Systems - up to Maximum User Weight 125kg (20 Stone)
Lot 21 - Adaptive/Modular Seating Systems - Minimum User weight 125kg (20Stone)
Lot 22 - Static Seating Systems - Maximum User Weight 50kg (8 Stone)
Lot 23 - Static Seating Systems - User Weight range from 50kg (8 Stone) to 125kg (20 Stone)
Lot 24 - Static Seating Systems - Minimum User Weight 125kg (20Stone)
Lot 25 - Adaptive Back Supports
Lot 26 - Repairs and Maintenance
Lot 27 - Managed Service
The framework is to be available for use by NHS Trusts and other UK public sector bodies in England,
Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland including those operating in both an acute and community
environment, clinical commissioning groups, GP Practices and other health and social care providers
(including any future successor organisations). It is recognised that primary use of the framework will be
by participating authorities in England. These are referred to as 'Participating Authorities' and further
details are included in Schedule A7 of the ITT.
